The reason why %97 of diets fail is because many people associate the word "diet" with a time connotation. I.e "I'm going on a diet for this summer" or "I'm going on a diet so I can fit into this dress" and usually once that period of time has passed they go back to their daily eating habits which caused them to put on weight in the first place.

Healthy weight loss is 1 to 2 pounds a week. (That doesn't sound like a lot but Google what 1 pound of fat looks like.) but in order to do that you need to burn 3,500 calories in one week, so you need to burn 500 calories Monday through Sunday. That doesn't mean you have to go to the gym every day in order to do so, you could start by parking furthest away from a certain venue and walking that small extra distance to the entrance and once you get used to that extra daily activity only walking to and from the venue.

Easiest way to start is by gradually cutting out soft drinks, alcohol, tea and coffes and only drinking water.

This video painted out low-carb diets to not be so great, but I, along with many other people I know as well as on the internet have lost a lot of weight on low-carb diets. I was never obese, but was overweight at 5'8M and 180lbs. Did Atkins 40g and went down to 150lbs in about two and a half months. I feel like the video, while having good intentions, kind of misunderstood exactly what low carb is about.

The video talked about how eating low carb could promote consumption of things like high-fat red meats and cheese. This part is true, I ate a lot more red meat and dairy. He is also right in saying that these foods are not the healthiest to eat in high amounts. But where I feel like he goes wrong is he acts like people stay on very strict low carb diets for the rest of their life, this is simply not true. Low carb diets are intended for you to lose a lot of weight fast, but you aren't meant to stay on a very strict low carb diet once you lose all that weight. I did eat unhealthy meats and cheeses on atkins, but once I lost the weight I implemented a 90g carb diet that would maintain my weight. I no longer eat high amounts of meats and cheeses, and eat a lot of vegetables and fruits now.

Think of the long-term pros vs cons. A low carb-diet may in the short-run lead to high consumption of some unhealthy things, but imho that brief period that eventually leads to massive weight reduction is way worth it in the grand scheme of things. Obesity related diseases are the #1 killer in the U.S. and its not even close. I think its worth it to go on a diet that may be unhealthy in some ways, but in the end massively mitigates the potential for you to suffer from something that is even more unhealthy.

I’m not an expert on dieting. I’m an English teacher. One thing which many people don’t realize is that eating is actually a form of communication, it can be a symbol of misery. What we choose to eat, when, and how much, are an integral part of our daily lives. So when people get fat by overeating, the solution is not just to diet and exercise. Many people eat too much as a response to loneliness. So to cure the problem of being overweight, you also have to cure the problem of being lonely. Look at this chart: https://www.instagram.com/p/B9h_95NgZ4G/?igshid=yyu8wnfdtg3g. You will see that being overweight is a source of shame. People who are ashamed tend to isolate. And when they isolate, they eat more out of loneliness, and self-hatred, Now look at this chart: https://www.instagram.com/p/CCWzfL0Ds_R/?igshid=x8v1f4fpqd1y. It shows that there are three types of loneliness: collective, social, and intimate. In order to break the cycle of self-punishment, an overweight person must cure all three types of loneliness. That means developing better relationships. And a greater number of relationships. The more friends and acquaintances, the better. Increased friendship and intimacy with other people will reduce feelings of loneliness; which will reduce the feelings of being stigmatized; which will reduce the self-destructive tendency of eating too much. Go to Church, Volunteer, join a Hiking Club. Anything which widens a person’s social circle will lead toward less loneliness, and greater self-esteem. People with high self-esteem take responsibility for their own future. So really, there is no such thing as a “diet”. There are only lifestyle choices. One choice is to stay at home, and be sad. The other choice is to engage the world, make a lot of friends, and be happy. People who are happy make better choices.

Edit:
I would like to make a few things clear, since many replies aren't understanding my meaning.

1. This comment was not meant to be a joke. I take mental health and eating disorders very seriously, and would never joke about them. They are serious issues, especially today, and should not be joked about, as it can make people who have had to deal with these issues feel that their problem doesn't matter to anyone else.

2. I know what bulimia is. Bulimia is an eating disorder in which you binge food and then force yourself to throw it up, making many of the calories consumed void, like you haven't eaten much at all. The point wasn't necessarily that you didn't put food in your mouth, but that many of the calories consumed were in one way or another disposed of before the body could use them as fuel.

3. There was a comment that brought up intermittent fasting. This is different to an eating disorder because you still get the calories that you need in a day, and so while you can still loose weight from it, it's a healthy and safe alternative to developing an eating disorder. Please do note that with certain other medical issues, like diabetes, intermittent fasting may not work, and could even have serious detriments to your health. Also note that I am not a doctor, but have learned this from personal experience.

I hope this edit clears a few things up, for those whining in the replies of this comment.

different diets work for different people, people who don't do exercise are likely going to have the most success with the keto diet (mostly fats) or intermittent fasting (not eating any foods at all). While someone who does a lot of aerobic exercises (like running) likely will benefit from lots of carbs and someone who does a lot of anaerobic (weight lifting) will likely benefit from paleo or high protein diets. There is a constant debate usually between high carb v ketosis diets, but there shouldn't be a debate, to begin with. We need to focus on giving people diets that work for different needs rather than decide on one diet that everyone sticks to.

"A" diet does not make sense. Everyone is on a diet. The only diet that is real is what you eat over the course of your entire life. It's countless small choices you make every day. Most monolithic "diets" fail because they miss the point of consistent, good nutrition. If you start a diet with an end date in mind, you have already failed. If you diet just for a summer beach body, you have already failed. If you change your diet for any reason other than your health, you have already failed.

That being said. Eat as much as you want of whole foods, and pass on foods with refined sugars and carbs which have been stripped of their nutrients. "Fortified with minerals" is honestly no better than the unadulterated refined junk - Pop-Tarts are "fortified", but are no better than candy. Don't worry about ingredients you can't pronounce, just CHECK THE AMOUNT OF SUGAR. Absolutely do not drink soda or juice. Get lots of fiber from nuts, seeds, and bulky vegetables like carrots, broccoli, and celery to promote a healthy colon.

Building A Righteous Bod: 5 Commandments Of Smart Dieting

To see the best results from any diet plan, you’ve got to know the “Diet Commandments”. These guidelines are essential for superior results. They will take you to the Promised Land, flowing with good health and energy.

Sadly, many dieters miss out on one or more of these rules, and it costs them their success.

Thou Shall Eat More Protein
Of all the foods you might eat while on a fat loss diet, protein is probably the most important. Protein combats hunger, stabilizes blood glucose levels, and prevents lean muscle loss. The result is raised metabolism and accelerated fat loss.

Don’t let your protein intake fall short. Aim to consume some in every meal and snack. For some unexpected sources of protein, consider quinoa, bulgur, avocado, and whole wheat bagels.

Thou Shall Eat Regularly
You may have heard that metabolism increases the more often you eat. That’s somewhat misleading. Actually, the boost you get from a meal is directly related to meal size — eating regularly does help keep hunger at bay.

Feed your body frequently throughout the day to avoid food cravings and energy lows. Those who follow this guideline are more likely to stick to their diet or weight loss program.

Thou Shall Prioritize Fresh Foods
When selecting your foods, remember processed foods are a sin. Eating fresh is a must. In our world, processed foods are around every corner, waiting to cause weight gain and thwart our efforts for a healthy life.

Eliminate processed food and give your diet a major boost. Focus on natural foods, like fresh fruits and vegetables, whole grains, healthy fats and oils, and lean proteins. This isn’t the Garden of Eden—reaching for the apple is the right choice.

You could call this commandment the Golden Rule of dieting. If you make only one change to your diet plan, make this one.

Thou Shall Set Short Term Goals
One diet rule that you should abide by is to continually set short term goals. Think about your strategy in the here and now, not months ahead. If your goals can only be achieved far down the road, it becomes too easy to lose sight of them.

You should also ensure that you put your goals in writing and tell a friend or family member about your intentions. The accountability will redouble your commitment.

Try thinking in two-week segments. Two weeks is generally the period necessary to form good habits, so it’s the perfect amount of time to build behaviors that stand the test of time.

This is precisely why The 2 Week Diet was created. It will help you stay motivated and consistent until good decisions become automatic.

Thou Shall Avoid Fruitless Comparisons
Finally, stop comparing yourself to others. Realize this is your journey. Your body is unique and you won’t see the same results as everyone else, so don’t expect to.

Instead, start comparing yourself today to yourself from yesterday. That will give you everything you need to know. If you improve every day, or hold fast to your diet program, then you are already a success.

Keep these diet commandments in mind. Focus on them and be confident you are building a truly righteous body.

TALK ABOUT KETOGENIC DIETS- They are way better than all the diets you suggested. Do some research.

Calories in calories out is a major red herring. A calorie of carbohydrate (say, sucrose) does not act on your body in the same way a calorie of fat or protein does. Sugars induce the release of insulin, a hormone which directs your body to use sugars as energy. Chronically high blood sugar means chronically high blood insulin levels, leading of course to insulin resistance typical of metabolic syndrome and T2 diabetes. Because insulin causes your body to burn mostly if not only carbs as energy, having chronically high insulin levels can make it difficult or impossible to lose fat that you have already accumulated, even if you're eating a caloric deficit. This is why ketogenic or similar low-carb diets are so successful for losing adipose tissue and weight - it removes those roadblocks of high blood sugar and high insulin levels that prevent your body from relying on your fat reserves as energy. Not only that, but it also reduces chronic inflammation and tissue damage caused by excessively high blood sugar (read up on what high levels of sugar does to your blood and veins, it's pretty gross)

This all means that YOU are STILL in control of your weight and what you consume. Calories in calories out just doesn't take into account the complex biochemistry involved with the digestion and processing of foods. It's also not to say that you should avoid carbs entirely, but rather stick to those which have gentle or negligible effects on your blood sugar, such as the complex carbs found in beans and whole grains.

One Fat Molecule contains 104 atoms of Hydrogen, 55 atoms of Carbon and 6 atoms of oxygen.
C55 H104 O6
To remove this one Fat Molecule from your body, You need to add or breath in 78 atoms of Oxygen to convert the Fat Molecule to 55 CO2 (carbon dioxide) molecules and 52 H2O (water) molecules.
The carbon dioxide you will ex-sponge from the body by means of exhaling and the water by urination.
Before your body can start a fat burn to remove one Fat Molecule, all the glucose in your blood needs to be depleted as will as the glycogen in the liver. The liver stores glucose energy in the form of glycogen. After blood glucose is use, the liver will convert the glycogen into glucose. After all the converted glucose are use up than the body will convert to the fat energy. This is called ketosis.
On an intensify workout when your heart rate is beating 60 to 80% of your Target Heart Rate (220 - your age ) It will take 45 to 90 minutes before glycogen and glucose are depleted and than the fat burn starts.
There are 3500 calories in one pound of body fat, so to burn half of one pound of fat off your body, you will need to extend your intensify workout with your heart rate @ 60 to 80% of your target for another 90 minutes
This is why working out to loss fat is useless unless you are already in ketosis with your carbohydrates intake under 50 grams.

I would like to point out two things... 1)  I designed sort of my version of a low-carb diet (my mother is a nutrionist) and lost 60lbs in 4 months. I merely cut out simple carbs, (I drank 23grams of sugar every time I worked out in the form of a canned iced tea), except the odd raw ear of corn as a snack,  and put NO restrictions on higher carb root veggies like carrots.  I was a little more conservative about beans but I ate chili every now and then in a decent portion size (1 to 1 1/2c), and in addition, I started walking.  I started walking at a 1/2 mile a day and worked my way up to 5 miles a day, and some days I would go and swim or do treadmill at the local rec center for a change of pace.  I wouldn't really count my daily carbs, and I ate tons more veggies than just huge amounts of red meats.  I'm not a big fan of pork anyway, so I wan't binging on bacon or ribs or anything.  Also, every now and then I'd just CRAVE pizza or bread or pasta to the point it would be something that would drive me absolutely nuts... So, I'd go eat it. (We're talking once a month or so, I'd eat two slices of pizza, or a cup of pasta).  Worked wonders and I found it really sustainable for me, until I came to Canada where I couldn't find a lot of the sugar-free foods I'd come to rely on.  (Sugar free chocolate cake mix+ Can of pumpkin = AMAZING CUPCAKES, by the way, for any kind of diet except gluten free, 200 calories and very low in carbs, relatively speaking) 2)The new weight watchers plan has veggies and fruits as 0 points, to encourage people to eat more of them, and an activity tracker and goals each week, to get people to also exercise, to get people moving.  The points system is now based on calories, saturated fat, sugar, and protein content. It's not merely calorie restriction.  That's what I do now and I've had success with it. I've lost 17 of the 30lbs I gained back after the move, in a month. (I have one of those metabolisms though, I lose weight pretty easily), and I still tend to choose not to eat simple carbs for my points, and go with more lean proteins, avoid cow's milk, (but I still love cheese, even a lower fat cheese is fine by me), and love a morning omelette.  I still avoid white sugar.

0:00There are...a lot of popular diets out there. So we thought we’d create a simple video
0:04investigating which ones are scientifically sound, and actually work.
0:08From the outside it seems like a simple equation: your weight is determined by the balance between
0:12the calories you take in, and the calories you burn. By changing what you eat or your
0:16activity level, you can tip this equation towards weight gain or loss. Which brings
0:21us to our first category of diets:
0:24Calorie Restriction. Companies like Weight Watchers claim you can eat whatever you want,
0:27as long as you stay below a prescribed number of daily calories. Getting all your calories
0:32from junk food is technically allowed, but from a health perspective, it’s important
0:36to think of the nutritional value of the foods too. If you don’t, you risk heart problems,
0:41nutrient deficiencies and chronic health issues.
0:43Calorie Restriction with Optimal Nutrition or CRON diets, generally reduce their caloric
0:48intake by 20% while still meeting the daily nutritional requirements. For example, instead
0:53of having a whole apple, a CRON dieter will just have the apple skin, which contains most
0:58of the nutrients.
0:59If used properly (and not excessively), calorie restriction can be a safe and effective tool
1:03for weight loss.
1:04Next up is Carb Restriction. Many diets like the South Beach, Atkins, or Zone Diet suggest
1:09that carbs are the enemy of the fit body you’ve always dreamed of.
1:13The ideology claims that when more carbs are taken in than burned off, the liver converts
1:17them into fats. But for most healthy, reasonably active people, carbs are broken down to glucose
1:23and transported to the cells for energy. Very little is actually turned into fat.
1:27In response to excessive glucose, the body uses insulin to turn it into glycogen, which
1:32is stored in the liver and muscles. This glycogen may later be broken down in times of low glucose,
1:37to refuel the body.
1:38But the type of carbs you eat do matter - those from simple sugars like honey, fruit or sugar
1:44are more readily turned into triglycerides or fat than complex carbs like whole grains
1:49and veggies. If you consistently eat way more than necessary, and most calories are simple
1:55carbs, then these will be converted to fat.
1:57Low carb diets often have extreme restriction at first; no starches like bread or pasta,
2:02and no sugars including from fruits or even alcohol. This can lead to some intense side
2:07effects, including constipation, dry mouth, bad breath, fatigue, dizziness and nausea.
2:12In studies, carb restriction dieters tend to lose weight faster, initially, compared
2:17to those simply using calorie restriction, but this is likely due to water loss, which
2:21returns in later phases when you’re encouraged to eat normally again.
2:25On top of this, the Atkins diet, for example, promotes caloric intake from high-fat and
2:29high-protein sources, which means meats, cheeses, cream, butter and...losing weight? Sounds
2:35pretty good right? But many doctors show concern over the high intake of saturated fat - that
2:41may lead to more ‘bad’ cholesterol and therefore an increased risk of heart disease.
2:45Some claim these kinds of diets are dangerous and unhealthy, given that they promote the
2:48limitation of foods like carrots, sweet potatoes, or apples, that provide the body with important
2:53micronutrients and vitamins. Instead, people require supplements, which the body is not
2:58able to absorb as effectively as vitamins, minerals and micronutrients in whole foods.
3:02Then there are High Protein Diets. The main principle is that protein rich foods are not
3:07as easily broken down by the body and take more energy to digest than carb-rich food.
3:12This means you won’t feel hungry again as quickly, and you’re more likely to run a
3:16caloric deficit than if you ate the same number of calories from carbs.
3:19The Paleo Diet, for example, suggests that 10,000 years ago agriculture was introduced,
3:24and the human diet changed from hunter-gathers eating primarily meat, wild fruits, veggies
3:29and nuts, to diets containing more grains. And as a result, some believe the human body
3:34isn’t designed to digest these processed foods like grains, dairy, and breads. Some
3:39also believe that grains lead to inflammation related health problems, but this is largely
3:43untrue except in the case of people with celiac disease.
3:47But because of it’s straightforward guidelines, many find it easy to follow, and it does promote
3:51more nutrient absorption. However, as paleo cuts out all grains and legumes, we lose an
3:56important source of dietary fibre necessary to keep our bowels running smoothly. Not to
4:01mention the high protein leads to nitrogen production meaning stinky farts! Add to that
4:07constipation which allows your digested material to sit longer in the large intestine and continuing
4:12to decompose and...yup. Smelly farts.
4:15Now there is another class of diets we might call the “Just Stop Eating” Diets. Those
4:20looking to ‘get slim quick’ might be tempted to only eat cabbage soup for 7 days, or do
4:25the ‘Master Cleanse Diet’ which only allows salt water in the morning and a concoction
4:29of water, maple syrup, lemon and cayenne pepper through the day, and a laxative tea at night
4:35- but these diets are exceptionally unhealthy. Not only is most of your weight loss from
4:39water weight, but there are many side effects such as dizziness, fatigue, dehydration and
4:43nausea.
4:44The Master Cleanse can ever lead to a white tongue, which some claim is the toxins leaving
4:49your body, but it’s actually due to swelling and a yeast infection of the mouth. And after
4:54going through all that, you’re likely to gain any weight lost after stopping.
4:57Then of course there are straight up crazy diets. Like eating cotton balls dipped in
5:01soup or juice so that you feel full, which of course provides hardly any nutritional
5:05content and can cause intestinal blockages which require surgical intervention.
5:10Or how about the sleeping beauty diet where you just...sleep? You can’t eat if you’re
5:15always asleep! The truth is most diets focusing on quick, dramatic results also have a ‘yo-yo’
5:21effect, where you lose initial weight but slow down your metabolic rate, so your body
5:25starts burning less calories. And when you start eating again...there’s all the weight
5:29back, and often more!
5:31After following contestants from the show ‘The Biggest Loser’ for 6 years - some
5:34of which who had lost hundreds of pounds in 7 months - scientists noticed something interesting.
5:40Not only did most of the participants in the study regain their weight, but their metabolic
5:44rates changed. One man in particular now burns 800 fewer calories a day than would be expected
5:50for a man his size! This is 6 years after leaving the show, showing how extreme measures
5:56to lose weight - while they may be successful at the time - have long lasting impacts on
6:01your metabolism, making it harder to keep off weight in the future.
6:04The hard truth is, that even using many of the principled diets, about 97% of people
6:09regain everything lost and sometimes more within 3 years. If you want to lose weight,
6:15finding a diet that works for you and keeps you motivated, with small incremental changes
6:19is important. Of course, a number on a scale doesn’t measure how healthy a person is,
6:24though many struggle with this perception. If food and weight preoccupations are a problem
6:29for you or someone you know, check out the description of this video for links with more

The part with the YOYO effect is wrong, YOYO just means you gain weight after you lost some, which is due eating more calories than you should because you are not restricting yourself anymore and start eating more than you should, also your metabolism is NOT slowing down
Example: you need 2500 calories(kcal) to maintain your weight of xxx pounds, after you reduced your daily intake to 1200 calories(kcal) your weight reduces to x pounds, since your weighing less your body also needs less kcal(because they body is moving less weight through the day, and NOT because your metabolism magically slowed down!!), which means that now with your weight being x pounds you need just 2000kcal a day which means if you now start going back to eating 2500kcal a day you will gain weight again(till you are weighing xxx pounds again), and THAT is called YOYO effect!

Perhaps the stupidest thing in the world is people saying "This diet works great everyone should try it"

Human beings come in all different configurations/metabolisms. Some are overweight because they don't exercise, some are overweight because of their diet, some are overweight because of genetics, some are overweight because of various diseases, some people are overweight because they're stressed.

So please stop with the bullshit "this diet works it's what everyone should do"

People who currently have unhealthy levels of stress in their lives might gain weight on a given diet that would result in them losing weight under less stressful conditions.

Our bodies are incredibly complex and the sheer idiocy of saying "Just eat boiled rat testicles, they'll make your hair curly" to a bald man is that...idiocy.

Because we can't say what is optimal for an individual we have to use science and look at what appears to give the best outcomes.

The really tragic thing is that we have all these people running uncontrolled experiments with themselves in the starring role as guinea pig...but if they were selected as guinea pigs for real learning/genuine understanding, they'd squeal like...uh...well...ahem.

Science: It's what distinguishes us from eggplant. So quit with the rumor mongering and the gossip and the anecdotes and look at what we actually know, a.k.a. the science. That's what the channel is about.

I need to get some facts straight about low carb diets, this video gave only a basic explanation. The reason you cut out carbs is not to avoid them getting stored as fat, its rather to burn fat (using ketones for energy) instead of glycogen. The problem is, it takes about a few weeks before your body develops the metabolic machinery to be able to do this. In that time you will often have horrible side effects as your body and brain need carbs to function, this is what leads you to crave carbs, give in and "yo-yo" the weight back on. If you are very motivated and know what you're doing, this is the most effective fat loss diet. Also if you stick to it for a month or more, then you will be okay whenever you cut out carbs as your body will use ketones for energy.

> Eat a healthy amount of food. (Going by calories Try to maximize the amount of nutrients you get, and minimize salty/sugary/greasy things. (You can stop on special occasions such as birthdays, weddings, etc) There are no such things as "super foods". Try to increase the variety of food you eat. You do not need to get 100% of your daily intake of all nutrients. Supplementary pills are unnecessary, unless you have a deficiency. If you believe you have a nutritional deficiency, contact your doctor and do as they say, by the letter. Stay healthy.

> Move a mile per day. (outside of your schedule. walking around at work/shopping doesn't count) You can split it into two, three, four, or even thirty parts. You can walk, jog, and sprint but try to go a little faster if you think you can, it exercises your heart (the heart is a muscle just like any other. Instead of moving you, it moves your blood) which will make many parts of your life better. It doesn't matter. Just. Go. I do not recommend gyms. I find them to be highly stressful environments. Stress isn't good for you. Walk around your neighborhood. Try to find some friends to go with, and chat with each other. Make sure to keep yourself hydrated. You may notice that this is the longest paragraph. This is because it is the MOST important part of losing the weight itself, so it's a bit complex.

> Be in control. No, I'm not talking about a carefully mandated caloric intake with military restrictions, and punishments. I mean the weight loss itself. Once you get to a healthy weight for you, you're going to have to stop losing weight, and not gain any. Make sure you can stop losing weight when you have to, or you will be in a dangerous situation. Getting a perfect 0 weight gained/lost per week is impossible, so don't sweat it if your weight varies a bit.

> Heads up: The less you weigh, the harder it is to actually lose weight. With this plan, you should lose weight well past a healthy weight but losses will slow down. It's normal. Don't worry.

> Stay positive about it. You're going to get better. (Go you!) As long as you're heading for a healthy weight for you, it's all good. This is perhaps the most important part of this. Never mind that, anything.

Hope I managed to help somebody. Peace!

When I was 14, I went to some rather extreme measures to lose weight. Every night I would calculate the calories I ate that day, and I would always try to find ways to eat less. I remember weighing myself maybe about 5 or 10 times a day. Most of the time I ate 720-730 calories at most in a day, and less on weekends since I didn't have to worry about covering up my problem by eating lunch at school
When I was 15, I was able to get myself to eat more normally again, but unfortunately I had a lot of weight gain over the years after. What really doesn't help is that I didn't take P.E. in grades 11 or 12 since we didn't have to, and in grade 12 a LOT of stressful (and frankly, traumatic) stuff happened in my life, causing me to stress eat quite a bit.
I don't know how much I weighed by the time I graduated, but at my lowest weight I was about 120 pounds, and a few years later I think I was 215 or so pounds? Give or take, I'm not entirely sure. But considering the fact that when I started the extreme dieting I estimate I was about 150 pounds, you can really see the difference it makes when you start an extreme diet, and when you go back to healthy eating.
Now I have a pretty physical job (I work in a depot) and I'm trying to eat better and get back into regular exercise by going to the gym, and I'm about 195-200 pounds at this point of time. I have to be careful though, because I have a tendency to go to extreme measures, and I DON'T want to go through what I did again!
It's a long process to get healthy after going on an extreme and unhealthy diet, so honestly, what's best is to just eat healthy and get some regular exercise!

Psychology:

B. Finish your food - this is also ridiculous, eat until you are satiated

C. Ask yourself if you are truly hungry or if you are craving. Learn to differentiate between eating for sustenance and eating for social, emotional reasons

D. Eat only when truly hungry

a) Start a low carb high fat diet at first to get your appetite under control, learn to listen to your body

b) once you have control over appetite and impulses you can eat what you want with the exception of highly processed foods with things like high fructose corn syrup

Ultimately, everyone has their own self imposed ambitions on which diet is best. Some believe no carbs is the healthiest diet. Some believe high carb content is the healthiest diet. Some believe gluten free is the healthiest diet. Some believe a heavy meat diet is the healthiest diet. Some believe goat cheese and milk is some sort of health food while cow cheese and milk is not (I suppose because it is ‘exotic’ — a new twist to what you have already become accustomed to).
We don’t really know which diet is the healthiest diet. We just believe things of our own accord.
Studies don’t tend to prove anything. There are a lot of factors that studies don’t tend to eliminate. For example, concluding that a McMuffin from McDonald’s causes inflammation because of the meat, dairy, and eggs is sort of flawed while there is wheat in that very same product and wheat is a known cause of inflammation. Another example is concluding that a carbohydrate free diet is healthy when you removed white bread along with healthier, whole types of bread. Of course if you remove white bread, the diet will be healthier; what about orher types of bread, though? Seperate the two! Get a fair answer!
We need studies that seriously are counsious in avoiding a flaw that therby affects the conclusion if we want a straightforward answer to “So, which diet is the healthiest diet?”

Me and a friend of mine lost weight the same way(i lost 30lbs and he lost about the same amount when we were in our teens). I lost weight then he did the same thing a year or two later and when he did it he found out the diet we were doing was actually a pre-existing diet called intermittent fasting or something. If you sleep from 10pm-6am the meal should be somewhere between 3-5pm everyday, adjust the time based on your sleeping schedule obviously and try to stick to the same meal time every day, eat the meal within 1 hour, the goal is to go 23 hours without eating everyday, the body is adaptive, it will get used to the reduction in food or number of meals in 1-2 months tops. The diet works best if you stick to it but if you think itll be too hard or want to enjoy good food you can do cheat meals or even cheat days, the max cheat days you should do is 2(a weekend). I lost the weight by eating 1 bowl of cereal in milk for my daily meals(specifically rice krispies but any cereal is fine), my friend did it with oatmeal(idk how many he would eat in his daily meals, i would guess 2-3 packs). Just find a way that works for you, its important to do something you can sustain so its better to add 1-2 cheat meals/days than trying to diet too hard and breaking the diet completely. Id recommend eating 1 medium-large bowl of a relatively healthy cereal during the week days and eating a relatively healthy cheat meal on saturday and sunday, but try to do it with no cheat meals for 3-6 weeks and if it doesnt start getting easier(body getting used to it) or if you constantly thinking about food and worried about breaking the diet then add cheat a cheat meal saturday and/or sunday.

In fact, you'd die with out it (not that I'm claiming excessive amounts to be great for you). Please tell me what is specifically negative about these types of diets- and do not take it from a moral perspective as I like animals alive as well as in my mouth- both are great (hey, if I could get meat in a practical manner without them being killed, I'd be all for it).

Sure, diets like keto may raise LDL cholesterol. I'd advise looking into what types of LDL specifically it raises/lowers (as it does have trends)- but when many people are concerned about LDL cholesterol it's likely that they associate it with metabolic syndrome or heart disease. There are 5 primary factors of metabolic syndrome, obesity (primarily around the stomach), low HDL, high triglycerides high blood pressure, and of course high fasting glucose.

When one examines the effect of a keto diet on these metrics, it becomes apparent that keto (or ones similar to) have positive effect on nearly all of them. I want to make prominent that LDL is not even considered a primary factor as it relates to metabolic syndrome. A high-fat diet, in the absence of a high carb diet, produces favorable health effects- though, I would certainly avoid trans fats.

Take it from someone who was extremely fat: As long as you define a diet as something you do for a while and then eat normally again, any diet will fail. You put on weight due to eating, so you weren't eating normally in the first place. You have to learn to eat normally and then stay with it - for the rest of your life.

Step 1 my nutrition counselor told me was to look at all the stuff I was eating and drinking and identify how much nutrients and calories it contains, and then look around for things I also like, but which contain much less of e.g. saturated fats and pure sugars. And check with the doctor or nutrition counselor that the new choices don't have side effects. Your new way of eating will stay with you for a long time, and both side effects and trying to eat what you don't like will ruin the attempt to gain a healthier life.

And that was just step 1. In further steps you'd learn which nutrients your body needs to have at every time, even during periods of weight loss, and which ones you can afford to eat less than you burn. And which ways of burning away calories work best with your body.

It's very easy. Do following:
1. Don't eat anything for 14 hours everyday. Like have your dinner at 10 pm (e.g.) then until noon next morning, only water or coffee (black). Eat 3-4 meals for remaining 10 hours (1500-2000) calories.
2. Have first meal with lots of protein and some fibre. Like, peanut butter, bread, whey protein (if you need!!), eggs, oatmeal, nuts, etc. This will keep you full for 3-4 hours.
3. Then, have some complex carbs with proteins and veges like brown bread sandwich with avos, etc. Or, brown rice with sweet potatoes, cottage cheese, hummus, brocholli, etc. Do similar for dinner.
4. For snacks, have low fat greek yoghurt with nuts in it. Will keep you full.
5. Do some exercise, which brings your heart rate up.
You can even eat whatever for 1 day. Let's say anything on Sunday....pizza, cake, icecream, etc. Nothing other six days.
Do it for long term.

Hopefully, this helps someone.

To everyone complaining about a vegan diet and how it's dangerous: it's not, if you do it correctly. While some people need some sort of meat or dairy (iron deficient, etc.,) a lot of people do well on a no meat/dairy diet! It saves land, water, helps reduce world hunger, and helps stop animal suffering. If you can't or don't want to drop meat or dairy, the least you can do is stop buying leather/fur/silk/wool, and stop going to zoos, circuses, or places like Seaworld. Eat whatever diet suits your body best.

In the end, it's all about calories in / calories out to lose the weight. There's really no escaping that.

Eating healthy food is great to get healthy, but unless you eat at a caloric deficit, you're still not going to lose weight.

Most diets initially work because you're hyper aware of everything you eat and drink, and they're mostly a roundabout way of cutting out calories. Both fats and carbs have insanely high calorie densities, so with high one, low the other you probably create a deficit.

Most diets ultimately fail because people start eating like they used to after reaching their goal weight. Take some time to learn what your daily allowance is to maintain that weight. Get that into your system, and you won't yoyo back up. This is where you transition from diet to lifestyle change.

And to those who claim to have fast/slow metabolisms/thyroid issues: track your calories for a week, and be amazed at how wrong your estimates are.

A calorie restricted diet with good amounts of protein combined with exercise has helped me lose 20 pounds. The key point is a caloric deficit, the protein helps with satiety and protects muscles from being broken down. I also prefer foods with low caloric density (like veggies and fruits) over foods with high caloric density, because you can eat a lot more, volume-wise, with the former. But that's all there's to it. You don't need any more rules than that. Also, the "Biggest Loser" study which claims that diets permanently slow down your metabolism has some flaws, so I wouldn't consider it proof. Actually, there's a lot of other studies with much larger sample sizes that show that dieting does, in fact, not lower your metabolic rate beyond what's expected (the less you weigh, the less calories you need). However, I'm glad you included two very important facts: 1) no matter what you eat, even if it's processed and sugary, it can't turn into fat as long as you're not overstepping your caloric budget and 2) you need to make sustainable changes if you want your weight loss endeavors to succeed. If this means you have to start small, by all means do that. Anything is better than nothing. It took me many years to go from a diet based on junk food to a healthy plant based diet.

On the comment about fruit: caloric density matters much more than whether the calories come from simple sugar or not. Most fruits are very low in caloric density. It isn't really appropriate to state that "doctors warn that X may be the case" when studies have been done into the matter and have results that can be reported instead.
